title: Nike shut down Oregon Project project just two weeks after Alberto Salazar's ban
text:
Nike have shut down the Oregon Project facility less than two weeks after Alberto Salazar was banned for doping offences.

Despite publicly standing by the coach who led Sir Mo Farah to four Olympic gold medals, the sportswear brand has responded to the backlash over the US Anti-Doping Agency findings by closing the set-up, which Salazar helped found in 2001.

The decision was announced ahead of Sunday's Chicago Marathon, where Farah, who was at the Nike Oregon Project from 2011 to 2017, will be up against his former NOP team-mate Galen Rupp.

Nike have shut down Oregon Project facility less than two weeks after Alberto Salazar's ban

Former Salazar athlete Jordan Hasay, the second quickest US female marathoner in history, will also be running.

A memo from Nike CEO Mark Parker read: 'This situation, along with ongoing unsubstantiated assertions, is a distraction for many of the athletes and is compromising their ability to focus on their training and competition needs.

'I have therefore made the decision to wind down the Oregon Project.' The statement added: 'I want to reiterate that Nike has always tried to put the athlete and their needs at the front of all our decisions.

Salazar (centre) with Mo Farah (right) and Galen Rupp at the London 2012 Olympics

'While the panel found there was no orchestrated doping, no finding that performance enhancing drugs have ever been used on Oregon Project athletes and went out of its way to note Alberto's desire to follow all rules, unfortunately, Alberto can no longer coach while the appeal is pending.

'As we have said, we will continue to support Alberto in his appeal as a four-year suspension for someone who acted in good faith is wrong.'

Salazar was banned for four years on October 1 after being found to have trafficked testosterone, attempted to tamper with the doping control process, and administration of a prohibited method of infusion. He is appealing.
